prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ebonite feed heat‑set". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Ebonite Endeavor

'Twas brillig in the heatsink's gleam,
Where solder-sparks did whirl and beam,
The feed-pipes blazed with molten might,
And thermal whispers probed the light.

Beware the Voltex, child of steam,
Its conductance a crackling scream,
With tungsten teeth and copper-coil,
Its chassis wrought in trembling roil.

Prepare thy shield of bakelite bright,
Thy calipers of measured flight,
And gird thyself with circuit-seal
Against its technological zeal.

The Voltex surged with plasma-rage,
Its conduit-limbs did swirl and swage,
But swift and keen, the maker's hand
Unleashed precision's sharp command.

And sliced it was, with laser-keen,
The Voltex fell, its systems clean,
The feed-heat trembled, then grew still,
Defeated by mechanic skill.

And hast thou calmed the burning stream?
Come to my arms, my beamish dream!
O frabjous day! Calibrate! Sing!
The ebonite's triumphant ring!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Hondling's Keen

'Twas grimmard, and the steely shine
Did holk upon the whetstone's line;
All ground was the O1's clear edge,
Prepared to slice beyond the ledge.

Beware the Hondling's hollow grind,
Its steel-bright gleam that cuts untwined!
The blade that whispers, keen and stark,
With tempered tooth and carbon's mark.

He took his vorpal steel in hand;
Long time the razor-whettle scanned—
Then rested he by grinding stone,
Where glistered steel's percussive tone.

And as in holfing thought he stood,
The Hondling crept through steely wood—
It slashed and slithered through the air,
With metallic and grinding flair!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The keen-edged blade its work did do.
He left it dead, and with its head
He came triumphant from the shed.

And hast thou ground the Hondling's steel?
Come to my arms, my beamish wheel!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
The hondled blade has won the day!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "forged leaf scroll". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Verdant Vellum

'Twas brisk, and in the shimmer-glades
The forged leaf scroll now swirled and swayed;
All glimmer were the verdant blades
Where whisper-winds their secrets played.

"Beware the Scrolling Leaf, my son!
The curl that grips, the page that bites!
The frondent form can swift outrun
And slice through soft and tender lights.

Prepare thy quill of silver keen,
Thy parchment shield of tensile might,
And watch with eyes of emerald sheen
The shifting shadows of its flight.

He grasped his scroll-breaker bright,
Long searched the twirling forest glade,
Then sudden—with a spectral bite—
The Scrolling Leaf its ambush made!

One swift and silvered scroll-slice stroke,
He cleft the creature's spinning core,
The glimmering page asunder broke,
And silence fell on forest floor.

"And hast thou slain the Scrolling Leaf?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Calcrief!"
He chortled in his wild, wind-joy.

poem:
The Kiln-Keeper's Vigil

'Twas glarven, and the clayish cone
Did warp and wibble in the heat;
The firing sparked with shimmer-tone,
Where witness-shadows seemed to beat.

Beware the bending glazen might,
The forge that twists with molten spine!
Prepare thy tongs with ceramic sight,
And guard the kiln's electric line.

He gripped the handle, steeled and stark,
And watched the ceramic currents flow;
The tempering flame with scorching bark
Would either break or let it grow.

One sudden lurch! The vessel bent—
He caught its curve with deft-forged hand;
The ceramic spirit nearly rent,
But saved by skill's commanding stand.

And as he turned, the kiln-light gleamed,
Refracted through the cooling shell;
The glarven cone no longer screamed,
But settled in its fired well.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "lead type in a composing stick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Typeset Tumult

'Twas printish, and the metal's might
Did press and plunge with linnard skill;
All sluggish were the letter-light,
And lead did glyph the composing trill.

"Beware the Setter's savage press,
The jaws that crush, the founts that bind!
The deadly quoin that seeks to stress
The page where printers' dreams entwined!"

He grasped the stick with steely grip,
His typeset blade went flicker-snack!
The Setter lurched with metal-clip,
But struck the forme with counter-track!

And hast thou slain the printing shade?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! The line is made!
The text cascades in printer's joy!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "urushi lacquer cure". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Urushic Gleam

'Twas glimpress, and the slivered shine
Did lacque and polish on the blade;
All membrant were the craftsman's line,
Where artful varnish softly swayed.

Beware the Urushic dire craft,
That stains with crimson crystal-wet;
With burnished edge and gleaming shaft,
Its surface none shall soon forget.

Prepare thy coat of hardened sheen,
Thy brush of silk, thy resin pure;
And watch with most attentive mien
The coating's slow and brilliant cure.

One sudden flash! The surface breaks,
The lacquer shifts in molten streams;
The craftwork trembles, shifts, and shakes—
Dissolving into prismic dreams.

And hast thou slain the varnish-wraith?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! With steady faith
The surface yields its secret joy.

'Twas glimpress, and the slivered shine
Transformed beneath the master's hand;
All membrant was the final line
Where art and matter softly stand.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Plumbrown Swirling

'Twas plumbing tide, and blueing bath
The staining suds did swirl and swale;
All murky were the watery paths,
Where chromic currents rose and wail.

Beware the Stainous Drifting Gloom,
The splash that seeps, the tint that creeps!
Arm thyself with scrubbing bloom,
And guard the porcelain's deep sleeps.

Long had the grayish waters churned,
With soapish whirls and sudding might;
When sudden through the foam there burned
A gleaming chromic creature's light.

One, two! One, two! The loofah slashed!
The cleaning blade went snicker-snack!
It rinsed the lurking tinge that flashed,
And drove the staining shadows back.

And hast thou cleansed the plumbrown tide?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
The bath now shines with pure alloy.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Partingmost

'Twas bristing, and the trainful tide
Did whirr and whistle sharp;
The platformed souls all stood astride,
With satchels wrapped and taut.

Beware the farewell's lurking ache,
The grief that gnaws and galls!
Prepare thy heart for partings' quake,
Where silence softly calls.

The whembling moment trembles near,
The glanceful eyes now meet;
A wordless wave, a misting tear,
Where memory and moment greet.

One swift embrace, one final clasp,
The whistle's shrilling swell,
One breathless, burning, breaking gasp—
Then nothing more to tell.

And hast thou bristed through the pain?
The platform stands bereft;
The train dissolves across the plane,
With silence all that's left.

poem:
The Inkish Fraye

'Twas brink, and through the scritchy page
The inker brayer did cascade;
All scrawly were the scripted rage,
And chase-lines writhed unswayed.

Beware the Markish Scriven-form,
The quill that slips, the ink that stings!
Prepare thy nib with warrior's norm,
And gird thy pensile wings.

The glyptic beast with scratchy claw
Came whiffling through the textured glen;
It skritched and skramped without a pause,
A typographic ken.

One fierce torque of the writer's hand,
The brayer struck with cutting might;
It cleaved the creature's ink-drenched brand
And ended graphic fight.

"And hast thou slain the Scriven-thing?
Come to my arms, my beamish scribe!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
The page began to tribe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "summit prayer flag". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Windwhisper's Creed

'Twas highmost, where the ridgelines gleam,
And prayer flags whisper thin and bright,
The windwhisk wandered, pale supreme,
With banners dancing keen and light.

"Beware the summit's sighing breath,
The clouds that curl with spectral spin,
Where altitude implies a death
Of gravity's familiar din!"

He grasped his staffrod, keenly set,
With windward weave and mountain-might,
And sought the peakish silhouette
Where spectral currents sparked their flight.

The windwhisk coiled with silvered wing,
Its phantomweave a spectral dance,
While flags their sacred murmurs bring
And mountain shadows held their trance.

One swift descant! One piercing call!
The windwhisk struck with spirit-blade,
And through the high celestial wall
Its sacred challenge boldly swayed.

"And hast thou cleaved the summit's spell?
Come to my arms, my beamish breath!"
He chortled in his windward swell,
Triumphant o'er the heights of death.

'Twas highmost, where the ridgelines gleam,
And prayer flags whisper thin and bright,
The windwhisk wandered, pale supreme,
With banners dancing keen and light.

poem:
The Luthier's Sonorous Strife

'Twas stringwise, and the crafty hands
Did gyre and gimble through the wood,
With soundpost setter's swift commands
To tune where muted timbres stood.

Beware the Warbling Hollowform,
The strings that screech, the curves that bend!
The deadly bridge that shifts its norm,
Where resonance might snap or rend.

He gripped his tool of tempered steel,
With ringèd gauge and caliber,
And through the violin's tender seal
He sought the phantom's tremor.

One sudden thrust! The soundpost slid,
Precise and true beneath the arch,
The spectral tone-wraith's song was hid,
Its dissonance beneath his march.

And hast thou slain the wavering voice?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous craft! Sweet sonic choice!
The instrument reclaims its joy.

poem:
The Night-Blooming Wariance

'Twas lurking in the mooncast glade,
The cereus-bloom its vigil made,
With tendrils pale and petals bright,
Awaiting some ethereal fight.

Beware the spectral stemward creep,
The tendrils that so softly sweep,
The whispering roots that writhe beneath
With silvered, silent, spectral wreath.

Prepare thy lance of starlit dew,
And gird thy spirit's ghostly hue,
For in the shadows, pale and thin,
The wariance stirs its ghostly spin.

With gleamish thrust and wildshard cry,
I pierced its luminescent sigh,
And through the bloom's translucent veil,
The phantom's whispers start to pale.

Triumphant 'neath the mooncast glade,
Where first the spectral vigil swayed,
I turned, the wariance now undone,
As night-bloom fades with breaking sun.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Syntherwock

'Twas moddy, and the synthy grid
Did tangle wires with tangled glee;
All patchy were the cable kids,
Connecting sounds most wild and free.

Beware the Patch-Snake, my dear friend!
The leads that twist, the jacks that snap!
Its tendrils crawl without an end,
Through voltage's electric trap.

Prepare thy jack and solder bright,
With circuit board and crosspatch drawn;
The modular machine takes flight,
Where signal paths are madly spawn.

He gripped his patch cord, firm and true,
And sent the signal burning bright;
The Patch-Snake shrieked a wild taboo,
And crumpled in electric might.

And hast thou slain the Patch-Snake dire?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Connecting wire!
The modular returns with joy.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "cassette wow and flutter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Flutterous Tape

'Twas warble, and the sonic tide
Did wow and writhe in magnetic glide;
All fluttery were the cassette reels,
And analog warped its steel-spun wheels.

Beware the Flutter-Drift, my son!
The waves that warp, the sounds that run,
The hissy tracks that splice and spin—
Keep sharp thy head, keep keen thy din!

He gripped his deck with crystal guard,
His playback poised, his listening hard;
Through wobbling waves of tape he strode,
Where Flutter-Drift had long abode.

One, two! One, two! The spindles whirled,
The magnetic monster soon unfurled—
He caught its trembling sonic phase,
And cut its warbling, wobbling ways!

"And hast thou slain the Flutter-Drift?
Come to my arms, my beamish gift!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his triumph's sway.

'Twas warble, and the sonic tide
Did wow and writhe in magnetic glide;
All fluttery were the cassette reels,
And analog warped its steel-spun wheels.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Chromatic Quest

'Twas opalline, and gleamish bright,
The chorish waves with splendor sung,
Where luminous and lithesome light
On prismic currents softly swung.

Beware the chromic flash, my child!
The spark that darts, the ray that springs,
The color-burst so quick and wild
That through the spectral dimension rings.

Prepare thy lens and crystal shield,
And gird thy spectral-catching blade,
For in the luminescent field
Where rainbow fragments swift cascade.

The opalescent surge arrives—
A whirling, twirling, glimmerous form,
Its prismic pulse and radiance drives
A scintillant and blazing storm!

One sharp refract! Two gleaming cuts!
The chromic beast is split asunder,
Its spectral heart now splits and shuts
With iridescent flash and thunder.

"And hast thou slain the color-wraith?
Come to my arms, my beamish knight!
O frabjous day! O luminaith!"
He chortled in his radiant might.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "peony ants at dawn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Peonyant's Peril

'Twas peonant, and the dewy dawn
Did skimble-scuffle through the lawn,
Where antling swarms with silvered wing
Emerged to dance and softly sing.

Beware the Peonyant, my child!
The jaws that crunch, the steps that wild,
The mandible that snips and slays,
The creature of the misty ways!

He gripped his thorny garden-stake,
Prepared to meet the swirling shake
Of chitined armies, red and bright,
That skittered at the morning's light.

One, two! One, two! The battle sang,
And through and through the petals rang,
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing home to bed.

And hast thou slain the Peonyant?
Come to my arms, my beamish grant!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
The dawn-bloom trembles far away.

poem:
The Scopish Sway

'Twas scintill, and the lissome light
Did warp and warble wave by wave,
Where oscillic rhythms, crisp and bright,
Traced patterns no plain sight could save.

Beware the Lissard's dancing line,
Its curves that curl in spiral song,
Its frequency-flung sharp design
That slices signal swift and strong.

Prepare thy probes and calibrate
The membrane of thy circuit's mesh,
While phantasm traces gyrate
In phosphor-painted, pulsing fresh.

The Lissard bloomed with sine-swept might,
Its graphing tendrils sharp and keen,
It scrolled across the spectral height
With harmonic and humming sheen.

One critical and calibred stroke
Dissolved its wavering wild display,
The tracing thinned, the pattern broke,
And silence claimed its measured sway.

And hast thou slain the Lissard's form?
Come to my arms, my beamish spark!
O frabjous phase, o windowed norm!
The scopish sway now leaves its mark.

poem:
The Civetic Swell

'Twas scentsong, and the musky breeze
Did warp and weft through perfumed trees,
All mizzled were the whisker-wraiths,
And misted were their scentful faiths.

"Beware the Civick's trailing musk,
The whiff that marks its spectral tusk!
Avoid its drift of pungent spray,
And shun its aromatic sway!"

He grasped his fragrant blade so keen,
With sillage sharp and notes between,
Long searched he through the misty glen
Where scented shadows stalked again.

One burst! Two lunge! And through and through
The fragrant beast its essence threw,
He left it drowned in its own tide,
Its whispered notes now nullified.

"And hast thou slain the Civick sharp?
Come to my arms, my beamish dart!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Cahay!"
He chortled in his scentful way.

'Twas scentsong, and the musky breeze
Sang soft through perfumed memory's trees.

poem:
The Reglet's Reverie

'Twas borgle, and the slumped reglet
Did gyre and gimble on the slab;
All furnish'd were the writhen set,
And rested in its wobbly grab.

"Beware the Chiffonier's dark reach,
O weary craftsman, shun its fold!
The jaws that grip, the hands that breach,
Where timber twists and stories told!"

He took his vorpal saw in hand;
Long time the furnish-foe he sought—
So rested he by dresser's strand,
And stood awhile in thoughtful thought.

And as in uffish pose he stood,
The Chiffonier, with woodgrain gleam,
Came whiffling through the workshop's wood,
Its drawers aslant with spectral scheme!

One, two! One, two! His saw-blade flashed,
He cleft its jointings clean and true;
The furnish-beast went crashing, smashed—
He left it split, its rage now through.

"And hast thou slain the Chiffonier?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Caheer!"
He chortled in his crafting joy.

'Twas borgle, and the slumped reglet
Did rest upon its conquered ground;
All furnish'd were the writhen set,
With silence now its only sound.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Crimping Crag

'Twas cleft, the raddled rockface sheer,
Where piton-wounds still glimmered pale,
And scraggled crags with scarpèd snare
Pervolved across the stony trail.

Beware the Clinchspike's jagged grip,
Its riven ledge of razor-shine,
Where climbers' dreams might swiftly slip
And blood would stain the granite line.

Prepare thy carabiner brave,
Thy rucksack girt with steely coil,
The pathway past each stony cave
Demands thy most tenacious toil.

Then sudden—crack! The Clinchspike lunged,
Its serrate scale and splinter-spine,
Through crampon-dance the climber plunged
And struck with piton's keen design.

One sledge-struck blow! The monster fell,
Its ragged form forever stilled,
The mountainside rang out its knell,
The ancient scar at last was killed.

And as he turned, with triumph bright,
The climber knew the peak was won,
Where raddled rockface burned with light
And crimping crags salute the sun.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "loom shuttle pick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Weaverwick

'Twas glimmerweave, and through the shed
The loompick snarled its bristled thread,
All spindle-sharp the shuttle flew,
And wefted warnings old and new.

Beware the Threadmaw's tangled grip,
The claws that rend and snare and rip!
The jaws that weave with razored might,
That twist the fabric day and night.

Prepare thy shuttle, tempered keen,
Thy warp-blade bright and spinning sheen,
With shuttle-sword and pick-mail strong,
To face the beast where threads belong.

And as it writhed with silken roar,
The Threadmaw lunged from warp-core floor,
But swift my shuttle-blade did swing
And cleave its web-wound wavering.

One crushing stroke! The fabric split,
The creature fell, its pattern quit,
And with my shuttle raised on high,
I wove its fate beneath the sky.

And hast thou slain the Threadmaw wild?
Come to my loom, my weaving child!
'Twas glimmerweave, and through the shed
The loompick snarled its bristled thread.

poem:
The Tinsong Strake

'Twas gleamish, and the smithy stake
Did ring and rangle in the glade;
All sparky were the molten flake,
And tempered rhythms softly swayed.

Beware the Straken's silvered cry,
The forge that flames with metal's might,
Where hammers dance and embers fly,
And sonic waves prepare the fight.

Prepare thy tongs and beating heart,
The resonance of craft supreme,
Where molten knowledge will impart
Its ringing through the sonic scheme.

The Straken bursts with clanging roar,
Its chromic scales of burnished light,
With ringèd song from core to core,
It challenges the smithy's height.

One ringing stroke! One thundered blow!
The tinsong breaks its metal spine,
And through the glade, the echoes flow
Of victory's resounding line.

And hast thou slain the Straken bold?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day of craft controlled,
The tinsong stakes its rightful joy!

poem:
The Dura Dazzle

'Twas glimst, and in the marbled light
The tessrae shimmered keen and bright,
With stoneshine quartered on the floor,
Where inlays whispered ancient lore.

Beware the Pietra's gleaming grip,
Its patterns sharp with cunning clip,
The mandral stones that slice and sing,
With chromic cuts on crystal wing.

Prepare thy loupe and steady hand,
With polished lens to understand
The secret pulse of marble's heart,
Where stone and vision shall not part.

And as the inlay-weaver came,
The Marblox writhed in tessered flame,
One crackling slice—a brillant stroke!
The stoneform trembled, cracked, and broke.

And hast thou slain the Marblox bright?
Come to my arms, my beamish might!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
The dura dazzles its display.

poem:
The Glimmerpause

'Twas bluehour's gleam on snowbound plain,
Where silvershard and frostlight wane,
And whisperwinds their secrets keep
Amid the crystal's dormant sleep.

Beware the Glimmerpause, my child,
The spectral drift, the radiance wild,
That shimmers where the silence flows
And azure luminescence grows.

Prepare thy lantern, gird thy might,
With quicken-glass and shimmerlight,
And watchful stance on snowfield's edge
Where phantoms dance along the ledge.

Then sudden—swift!—the creature rose,
A luminescent, spectral pose,
Its glinthing form, its prismed wing
Began its ethereal, spectral swing.

One stroke! One gleam! The moment passed,
The Glimmerpause dissolved at last,
And through the blue and silver sheen,
Returned the quiet, unforeseen.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Crosstrode Vigil

'Twas creoling, and the spindly ties
Did grime and gnarl along the way;
All creosote-rich winds would rise
To herald forth the breaking day.

Beware the Crosstrode's lurking breath,
Its tarry tendrils, slick and slow;
Prepare thy rail-worn blade of death,
And watch where twisted pathways go.

The Crosstrode slunk with woody stride,
Its pitch-dark form both sharp and sleek;
No sound save grinding tracks implied
The monster's hunt, its vengeance bleak.

One swift and singing stroke rang true—
The creature split from stem to root;
Its essence scattered, dark and new,
Dissolved beneath my iron boot.

And as I wandered trackside home,
The scent of victory did blend
With creosote and rail-track foam,
Where crosstrode whispers meet their end.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Collet's Quiver

'Twas springward, and the balant coil
Did quave and quertle in its nest;
The spryngèd collet, free from broil,
Lay waiting at its vibrant quest.

Beware the Tension's winding grip,
Its watchful wheel and torsion's might!
Prepare thy calibers to slip
And brace against its measured bite.

With measured step and calipered art,
The craftsman grasped his tempered blade,
And through the mechanism's heart
He struck where delicate lines were laid.

O frabjous skill! The spring uncoiled,
Its rhythmic pulse now set aright;
The mechanism pure, unroiled,
Sang triumph in its balanced flight.

And hast thou slain the wavering strain?
Come to my arms, my skillful boy!
The clockwork dances wild again,
With precision's resonant joy!

poem:
The Pantographic Prowl

'Twas brillig in the sparking shed,
Where pantographs their blue-arc spread,
The clipsome rails did glint and gleam,
With crackling currents' wild regime.

Beware the Voltaic Striding Beast,
Its lightning limbs from power released,
With crackling claws and sparking spine,
That leaps along the current's line.

Prepare thy contact-brush with care,
And polish every sliding snare,
The whirling wires above thee coil,
With conductory electric roil.

The Striding Beast with sizzling stride
Comes charging down the arcing ride,
Its voltant veins in brilliant burst,
With copper-crackled energy versed.

One swift connexion! Cleave its path!
With switchy sweep and contact's wrath,
The creature falls in sparking shred,
Its electric heartbeat swiftly bled.

And hast thou slain the Voltaic Thing?
Come to my arms, my crackling king!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
The pantographs have won the day!

poem:
The Stubble Swirl

'Twas murm, and o'er the shorn-down field,
The starlings swooped in wilding weave,
A dark-winged dance their forms revealed,
Where harvest's remnant paths did cleave.

Beware the swirling shadow-cloud,
That pirls and whirls in liquid flight,
Whose wingbeat-whispers, sharp and loud,
Cascade across the fading light.

Prepare thy gaze and steady stance,
As feathered phantoms curve and swell,
Their synchronistic, swooping dance
Performs a sky-born spectral spell.

And as the murmuration rolls,
Its living pattern sweeps and bends,
The stubble field its canvas holds
Where liquid motion never ends.

So mark the moment's wild careen,
The breathless, synchronized display,
Where bird-cloud drifts in silver-sheen
And harvests fade to ashen grey.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pewter inlay ribbon". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Ribbonwraith's Gleam

'Twas ribboncast, and slumbrous nights
When pewter shadows slunk and slid,
And inlay whispers, gossamer bright,
Through spectral chambers softly hid.

Beware the Ribbonwraith, my child!
Its silken tendrils, sharp and sly,
That weave and warp and writhe unriled,
With glimmering threads that glint and fly.

Prepare thy gleamish mettle keen,
And polish blade with ardent shine,
For in the chambers pale and lean,
Where spectral looms their secrets twine.

Then clashed we in the silver glade,
The Ribbonwraith with streaming art,
Its tissued form began to fade,
As swift my blade did slice and part.

And hast thou slain the woven thing?
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
The ribbonmist now takes to wing,
And pewter shadows slip away.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "linocut brayer chatter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Brayer's Bravado

'Twas bristle-bright, and linotype's gleam
    Rolled raucous through the print-strewn lair,
With chatter-scrape and roller-scream
    That whirled and whispeled everywhere.

Beware the Brayer's bristled might,
    Its roller-rage, its inky glee,
Whose scraping limb and slicing bite
    Could carve a raw typography!

He gripped his tool with fingers keen,
    The linocut before his blade,
And watched the shadows shift between
    The patterns that his press had made.

And as he stood in graphic stance,
    The Brayer with its razor-hurl
Came whiffling through the press's dance,
    Its edge a wild, cantankerous swirl!

One, two! One, two! His blade cut through
    The monster's ink-stained, skittering form,
With slicing stroke both sharp and true
    That rent its graphic-grappling norm.

"And hast thou slain the Brayer bright?
    Come to my arms, my skilled design!"
He chortled in his pressing might,
    Returned triumphant, line by line.

poem:
The Quarter-Sawn Shimmering

'Twas glimmer, and the silvered plane
Did slick and swivel through the board:
All quarterzed were the wooden grain,
And shimmerlight its surface scored.

Beware the Slicewood's dancing gleam,
The blades that whirl with keening might,
Where luminescent ribbons stream
And planes of polish take their flight.

Prepare thy sharpest cutting tool,
Thy steadiest and keenest hand,
For slivered light can swiftly fool
The worker in this woodlight land.

The Slicewood swirls with lustred spin,
Its wavelight dancing razor-keen,
And as it curves with silvered grin,
The cut erupts in gleaming sheen.

One ringing stroke! The plank divides,
The shimmer splits with sudden spark,
And through the grain the brightness glides,
Triumphant o'er the wooden dark.

And hast thou slain the Slicewood's dance?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous cut! Triumphant glance!
The quarter-sawn reflects our joy!

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Bluded Screwment

'Twas whirling, and the scintil spin
Did gyre and gimble in the press;
All bluded were the crankish grin,
And mechanism's wild caress.

Beware the Screwment's gleaming eye,
The jaws that clamp, the twist that stings!
Prepare thy wrench with purpose high,
And guard against mechanic things.

The blued-bolt stalked with metallic stride,
Its threaded form in silvered light;
No gearward path could it abide,
Emerging from the mechanism's might.

One crisp rotation—sharp and true!
The crankshaft trembled, then was still;
The Screwment fell, its motion through,
Defeated by consummate skill.

And hast thou slain the spinning beast?
Come to my arms, my valiant friend!
O frabjous day! Mechanized feast!
Where whirling motion meets its end.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "parrel bead on a gaff". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Parrel's Peril

'Twas gaffward bound, the rigging bright,
Where sailcloth whirled in windswept might,
Beware the parrel's gleaming bead,
That lurks where masted shadows speed!

The sailmaker warned with knotted hand,
"Shun swerving ropes across the strand,
For phantom lines with silvered sheen
Can snare the unwary, yet unseen!"

Prepared with splice and hempen guard,
I gripped the shroud both keen and hard,
When sudden from the billowed deep
The parrel-bead began to creep.

Its glimmer sharp, its motion wild,
A nautical phantom unbeguiled,
With sliding slip and twisting grace
It sought to bind me in embrace.

But swift my blade, my sailor's art,
I cleft its threading line apart,
The bead dissolved in spray and sound,
And nautical peace again was found.

Triumphant, I to deck returned,
Where ancient maritime tales burned,
And told my tale of ropes' swift dance,
The parrel conquered by my lance!

poem:
The Levainsome Loaf

'Twas breadscore, and the glutened yeast
Did rise and slacken in the bowl;
All floured were the counters greased,
And proofing caught its fervent toll.

Beware the sourdough's wild embrace,
The crumb that feeds, the starter's might,
With bubbling tongue and folding grace,
It waits to leaven appetite.

One, two! One, two! The baker's blade
Autolysed dough with tender care,
The ferment through its coursing played,
With gluten strands beyond compare.

And hast thou kneaded this wild loaf?
Come to my arms, my crusty friend!
O glutenous day! Halloo! Kerchloaf!
The bread transforms before the end.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sashiko boro patch". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Stitchsome Mend

'Twas mending, and the tattered cloth
Did weave and warp in threadly wrath;
All patchy were the boro seams,
And sashiko's soft starlit gleams.

Beware the Frazzle-Fade, my child!
The threads that fray, the weave that's wild;
Beware the Threadbare Bird, and shun
The frumious Fabric's ragged run.

He grasped his needle sharp and true,
With stitch-craft old and wisdom new;
Long time the mending-foe he sought—
So rested he by darning's thought.

And as in stitchful thought he stood,
The Frazzle-Fade, with seams unglued,
Came whiffling through the tattered park,
And ripped and rent with savage mark!

One, two! One, two! His needle bright
Went snicker-snack with mending might!
He left it torn, and with its threads
He came triumphant o'er its shreds.

"And hast thou mended the harsh tear?
Come to my arms, my beamish dear!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his threads' array.

'Twas mending, and the tattered cloth
Did weave and warp in threadly wrath;
All patchy were the boro seams,
And sashiko's soft starlit gleams.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nixie tube warm glow". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Nixoid's Nimbus

'Twas glimb, and the electron's light
Did pulse and preen in technic's glade,
All lumino were the circuit's might,
And the nixoid warmly swayed.

"Beware the Nixoid's radiant gleam,
The watts that sear, the volts that bite!
Shun cathode-spark, avoid its dream,
And guard thy circuitry from fright!"

He grasped his soldering iron keen,
Long seeking that ephemeral glow,
When burbling through the transistor's screen
The nixoid sparked its lambent show.

One, two! One, two! His iron flashed bright,
He battled with the spectral thing,
Until its luminescent light
Collapsed beneath his technic swing.

"And hast thou slain the nixoid clear?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in electric joy.

'Twas glimb, and the electron's light
Pulsed softly in the circuit's shade,
All lumino, the nixoid's might
Dissolved in technological glade.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Swirling Gouge

'Twas brisk, the swishel-tailing day,
When scouring sweeps would surge and play,
The gouging fin with gleaming might
Prepared to breach the watery height.

Beware the swirlish finned attack,
With razored edge and slicing track,
Where whirling currents spin and slice
And waters whisper fey advice.

Came glimmering through the churning tide,
The creature with its spectral stride,
Its scales a-glint with razor-keen
Precision of a slashing sheen.

One mighty thrust—a splashing crack!
The gouge-tail swept its challenge back,
And with a keen and cutting roar
Dissolved into the spray-flecked shore.

And hast thou slain the swirling beast?
Come to my arms, my beamish feast!
O frabjous day! Kallooh! Kalay!
The swishel-tail has swept away!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "letter kept in a cedar box". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Cedar's Secret

'Twas missive, and the papery page
Did crinkle soft within its cage,
All cedar-scent and whispers deep
Where ancient memories softly creep.

Beware the Letter's folded might,
Its secrets tucked from tender sight,
With edges frail and waxen seal
That trembles with unspoken zeal.

Prepare thy nerves and steady hand,
To lift the lid of this wood-land,
Where words like phantoms curl and swirl
And hidden truths begin to pearl.

The parchment rustles, crisp and thin,
Its murmurs echo from within,
A missive-wraith of ink and breath
That dances just beyond our death.

O frabjous scroll of silent lore,
Thy whispers crawl from shore to shore,
The cedar guards thy silent song
Where memory and myth belong.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Keyer's Klick

'Twas ditsing, and the signal's sway
Did morse and clatter on the line;
All tappy were the contact's play,
And signals slithered, sharp and fine.

Beware the Click-Key's ringing sound,
The tines that tap with metal might,
Where copper contacts swirl around
And electronic rhythms bite!

Prepared with brass and silver keen,
The operator tensed his hand,
His fingers poised, his purpose clean,
To send his message 'cross the land.

Then clicked he swift, with lightning strike,
His rhythm perfect, crisp and true,
No wavering dots could e'er dislike
The message coded, sharp and new.

And as the signals danced and sprang,
The Keyer's skill was manifest,
With every tap, with every clang,
His wireless spirit stood its test.

O frabjous tap! Callooh! Cahoot!
The message sent through ether's roar,
The Click-Key vanquished, absolute,
Returning silent as before.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Rosinmote

'Twas brillig in the dusty hoft,
Where scraping tones would skirl and drift,
The fiddler's bow, with sparkling soft
Would rouse the rosinmotic rift.

Beware the wibbling dusty shade,
The plucking fingers sharp and keen,
That scrapes and scatters, unafraid,
Along the strings' melodic sheen.

Prepare thy bow and tighten string,
The rosinmote might swirl and leap,
With whispering curl and bristle-wing,
From silence deep and music's keep.

And as it swirled with dusty might,
The fiddler struck a ringing blow,
Dispersing motes in wild delight,
And vanquished all its trembling glow.

And hast thou slain the rosinmote?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Calloat!
The music rings with pure deploy.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plane iron camber". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Camber's Keen

'Twas camber bright, and plane-wrought sight,
The iron wefts were slick and slung;
Beware the Sharpened Edge, my might,
Where blades have whispered and have rung.

Prepare thy guard with milled resolve,
With keenest edge and tempered steel;
The camber's curve begin'd to evolve,
A gleaming threat beyond repeal.

And as it sliced with shrilling swirl,
The iron daemon, razor-thin,
Its camber-blade began to curl
With metallic, slashing din.

One swift and silvered stroke I struck,
And cleft the spinning edge asunder;
The implement, once primed with luck,
Fell silent, split by martial thunder.

And hast thou slain the cutting thing?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! The blades shall sing
Of triumph's keen and bright alloy.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Orin Bell's Hum

'Twas hrimm, and the slithel brume
Did warp and weave through mystic gloom,
All shimmed the orin bell's low hum,
Where shadows dance and whispers come.

Beware the Glimmering Shade, my son!
The teeth that click, the wings that stun,
The creeping form with spectral might
That haunts the edges of twilight.

Prepare thy gleaming wardent blade,
And wind thy watchet scarves in raid,
With nerves of steel and spirit bright,
To face the phantasm's secret plight.

Then surged the Shade with crackling roar,
Its misty tendrils spread and tore,
But swift thy blade cut silvered arc,
And stilled its whisper, quenched its spark.

And hast thou slain the Glimmering Thing?
Come to my arms, my valiant king!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
The orin bell now softly sways.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Brinez Surge

'Twas glistrath, and the salty height
Did seethe and spume with brinal might,
All hissy were the wavecrests' swell,
And brinepangs pierced the oceanic spell.

Beware the Quenchling's searing lair,
Its misty breath, its saltward glare!
The fangs that drip with liquid fire,
The claws that make the sea suspire.

Prepared, I gripped my sparkling blade,
The foamweave glinting, coldly splayed,
And through the hissing brinepools strode,
Where liquid terrors slipped and flowed.

One slash! Two strikes! And through and through
The Quenchling fell, its salt-surge blue,
Its liquid essence rent and torn,
Its watery essence dashed and shorn.

And hast thou slain the Brinez thing?
Come to my arms, my beaming king!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
The salty surge has slipped away.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Blaggard's Knot

'Twas blimmock, and the badger's knot
   Did gnarble in the wold;
The bloomish tendrils, tightly caught,
   Ran wispy, wild, and bold.

Beware the Blaggard's tangled spine,
   Its rootish, knotted gleam!
With claws that twist and teeth that shine,
   It stalks beyond a dream.

Prepare thy bramble-battered sword,
   The twigging branch of might,
And listen for its scratching chord
   That whispers through the night.

Then sudden burst! The creature leaps,
   Its knottish form unfurled;
With snarl and snap, the battle sweeps
   Across the trembling world.

One mighty stroke! The blade descends,
   The Blaggard writhes and falls;
The wold in silence now transcends
   Its primal, knotted calls.

And hast thou slain the tangled beast?
   Return, with glory crowned!
The blimmock winds have now decreased,
   And silence stalks the ground.

poem:
The Nibmesh Quell

'Twas nibbly in the micro-shine,
Where tinery gleams so bright,
The mesh-wrought shadows intertwine,
And whisper cryptic might.

Beware the Nibmesh's razor-blade,
Its micro-tendrils keen,
The warning signals softly fade
Where silicon has been.

Prepare thy mesh-linked armor true,
And temper circuit-steel,
The glinting blades will slice thee through
If thou thy guard should steal.

With clangent surge and sparkling sweep,
The Nibmesh rends its path,
Its silicon-sharp talons leap
To spring its digital wrath.

One searing strike! The mesh-wire slants,
The creature splits and falls,
The triumph rings with crackling chants
That echo through the halls.

And hast thou slain the Nibmesh bold?
Return with data's pride,
Where micro-realms their secrets hold
And circuit-shadows glide.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Krenovian Skirmish

'Twas krellic in the planeward throat,
Where wingish shadows sliced and swirled,
And gimbrous winds their whispers wrote
Across the warped and whirling world.

Beware the Krenovian glint,
The fanged and flickering machine!
Its serried blades with metallic tint
Would slice where softer paths had been.

Prepare, O brave and trembling soul,
With grasping shield and humming blade,
To meet the thing beyond control,
Whose cold precision shall not fade.

Then clashed we in that screaming height,
With shriek and whirr and spinning gleam,
My strike cut through its wingèd might
And burst its mechanism's dream.

And as I turned, the silence sung
Of victory's resplendent arc,
The planeward throat where battle wrung
Its last melodic, silent mark.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "rain on a tin roof". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Rattle-Romp

'Twas drizzle, and the clinking tin
Did plink-plonk on the roof's broad spine;
The droplets swarled with rhythmic din,
A thunderous, metallic line.

Beware the Rainsung's clattering surge,
Its drumbeat wild and water-whirl,
The sonic beast that seeks to urge
Its liquid language out and curl!

Prepare with resonance and might,
With hollow helm and listening ear,
The soundscape trembling with delight,
As liquid rhythms draw so near.

Then crashed the Rainsung on the sheet,
Its pewter paws a-splashing wide,
With thunderous and tinny beat
It roared its watery loud pride.

One swift momentum—slice and slice!
The listener struck with echoed sound,
And silenced was the wild device
That sang its storm across the ground.

And hast thou heard the tin-roof's song?
Come rest, and listen to the tale
Of how the Rainsung, loud and strong,
Was vanquished by its ringing wail!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sencha kyusu drip". poem:
The Sencha Siphon

'Twas brewish day, and slippy steep
Where steams and strainers softly sway,
The kyusu poised, its vigil keep
On dripping leaves in jade array.

Beware the Teascape's misty might,
The steep that steals the senses clear,
Where vapors dance in whispered flight
And whisks of wisdom hover near.

Prepare thy vessel, bright and keen,
With filters gleaming silver-bright,
And gird thy palate for the scene
Of liquid lore's transforming light.

Then sudden—hark! The infusion springs,
A swirling, whirling leafy lord,
Its tendrils curl, its essence sings
A steeped and steaming water-chord.

One rapid pour! The draught is caught,
The sencha stills its wild careen,
And triumph of the brew is wrought
With clarity of emerald sheen.

And hast thou slaked thy thirst that day?
Come to thy senses, calm and pure,
The Teascape melts in wisps away—
Its magic brewing yet, for sure.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "split‑grade enlarger burn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Luminescent Marge

'Twas burnish, and the splitwise glare
Did churn through photoed chamber's lair;
All mimsy were the gradient frames,
That flickered near the darkroom's snares.

"Beware the Enlarger's searing might,
The lens that burns and blinds so bright!
Shun silver-sharp its spectral sheen,
And guard against its blazing bite!"

He took his vorpal loupe in hand;
Long time the focal foe he scanned—
Then rested he by chemical tree,
And stood a moment, lens-command.

And as in urgent thought he stood,
The Burn-Beast, with its molten mood,
Came whiffling through the paper's seam,
A searing specter from pure flood.

One, two! One, two! His loupe did slice!
He left it dead, and with device
Returned to light's reductive realm,
And triumph marked his contact's price.

"And hast thou slain the Burn-Beast bare?
Come to my arms, my beamish heir!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his chromic lair.

poem:
The Kiridashi Khorlag

'Twas scribe-bright, and the writhen line
Did gleam and glimmer sharp and fine,
The kiridashi blade so keen
Carved whispers where no script had been.

Beware the Khorlag's scribal rage,
Its inkblot tendrils slick with stage,
That snicks and scratches page and skin
With grapheme-claws that slice within.

Prepare thy nib and steady hand,
The parchment trembles 'cross the land,
With skreeling sounds of pending text
Where mystic markings stand perplexed.

Then slashed he with his vorpal knife,
And cleft the Khorlag's wordish life,
One sudden stroke of pure design
Resolved the fractal, fell combine.

And hast thou slain the scrawling beast?
The triumph rings from west to east,
The kiridashi gleams once more
As silence settles to its core.
